conversation.text: Hello. Today we will make icing for cinnamon rolls.
Can't wait to start it!
First heat the butter until it browns. Put 6 tablespoons (84g) of butter into a small saucepan. Set the burner to medium and stir until the butter melts.
evidence: Place 6 tablespoons (84 g) of butter in a small saucepan and turn the burner to medium. Stir the butter occasionally until it melts.

conversation.text: I have melted it. What should I do then?
Keep doing the same thing for one or two minutes until the butter has become golden brown. Then switch off the heat and move the saucepan to a cold ring.
evidence: Continue to cook and stir the butter for an extra 1 to 2 minutes so the butter becomes fragrant and turns golden brown. Turn off the burner and set the saucepan on a cold burner.

conversation.text: Done. Should I pour the butter onto rolls after it cools?
Not yet! Instead, weigh out 4 ounces or 115g of softened cream cheese. Put this into a medium-sized mixing bowl and add the butter to this instead.
evidence: Put 4 ounces (115 g) of softened cream cheese into a medium-size mixing bowl. Pour the melted butter into the bowl.

conversation.text: I see. Cheese and butter - what a calorie bomb!
Well everything is fine in moderation! Are you ready to do the next step?
Yes, let's move on!
Of course! Now, use an electric mixer - set the speed to medium - to beat the butter and cream cheese together until the mixture is light and fluffy. This should take two to three minutes.
evidence: Beat the butter and cream cheese for 2 to 3 minutes.
Use an electric mixer to beat the butter and cream cheese on medium speed until the mixture is light and fluffy.

conversation.text: I have finished it. Next step, please.
Okay! Listen up because this is quite complicated. You first need to beat in one cup of powdered sugar with the mixer set to low.
evidence: Turn the mixer to low and beat in 1 cup (125 g) of the powdered sugar.
Beat in 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of the milk and continue to mix in the rest of the powdered sugar 1 cup (125 g) at a time.
Beat in another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of the milk after each powdered sugar addition.

conversation.text: Okay, what do I do then?

Here you go: Now, beat in one to two tablespoons, or 15-30ml, of milk and mix in the rest of the powdered sugar one cup or 125g at a time. Remember to beat in another one to two tablespoons of milk after each cup of sugar. Does that make sense?
evidence: Beat in 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of the milk and continue to mix in the rest of the powdered sugar 1 cup (125 g) at a time.
Beat in another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of the milk after each powdered sugar addition.

conversation.text: It is sort of complicated. But I think I can handle it!
Good! Are you ready to do the next part?
Yes, please move on.
Sure. Now, beat in 1 1/2 teaspoons or 7ml of vanilla extract. The mixer can stay on low.
evidence: Keep the mixer on low and beat in 1½ teaspoons (7 ml) of vanilla extract.

conversation.text: Done. What's next then?
Do you want the icing to be thinner or are you okay with its current consistency?
The consistency looks good to me.
Great! Are you ready to ice the cinnamon rolls now or do you want to save the icing to use it a few days later?
evidence: If you want to make this icing in advance,

conversation.text: I want to eat it now.
Of course. All you have to do is scoop up the icing and spread it over the cinnamon roles. But check that they are completely cooled first before you do that!
evidence: Scoop and spread the icing over completely cooled cinnamon rolls.

conversation.text: Thanks! Can I eat it now?
Yes you may! Enjoy!

recipe.title: How to Make Icing for Cinnamon Rolls

procedure.summary: Heat the butter until it browns.
procedure.description: Place 6 tablespoons (84 g) of butter in a small saucepan and turn the burner to medium. Stir the butter occasionally until it melts. Continue to cook and stir the butter for an extra 1 to 2 minutes so the butter becomes fragrant and turns golden brown. Turn off the burner and set the saucepan on a cold burner.

procedure.summary: Measure the cream cheese into a bowl and add the melted butter.
procedure.description: Put 4 ounces (115 g) of softened cream cheese into a medium-size mixing bowl. Pour the melted butter into the bowl. The warm butter will soften the cream cheese even more.

procedure.summary: Beat the butter and cream cheese for 2 to 3 minutes.
procedure.description: Use an electric mixer to beat the butter and cream cheese on medium speed until the mixture is light and fluffy.

procedure.summary: Mix in some of the powdered sugar and milk in batches.
procedure.description: Turn the mixer to low and beat in 1 cup (125 g) of the powdered sugar. Beat in 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of the milk and continue to mix in the rest of the powdered sugar 1 cup (125 g) at a time. Beat in another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of the milk after each powdered sugar addition.

procedure.summary: Mix in the vanilla and adjust the consistency of the icing.
procedure.description: Keep the mixer on low and beat in 1½ teaspoons (7 ml) of vanilla extract. If you'd like thinner icing, beat in 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of milk at a time until it's as smooth and thin as you like.

Scoop and spread the icing over completely cooled cinnamon rolls. If you want to make this icing in advance, transfer it to an airtight container and refrigerate it for up to 5 days. You'll need to stir it well before spreading it over the cinnamon rolls. Most icings can't be stored in advance but the creamy icing keeps well because of the cream cheese in it.
